thread.title: There are two sides to the tort equation
thread.title_full: There are two sides to the tort equation - The Washington Post

author: John Woodrow Cox
title: There are two sides to the tort equation
text:
October 16 at 7:08 PM The Oct. 5 Style article “ Ralph’s House of Torts ” contained not a single Quote: from those of us who work to reduce abuse of our civil justice system and meritless lawsuits that undermine health-care affordability and investment in our still-troubled economy.
Though the new American Museum of Tort Law “reminds visitors how unhealthy American lives were . . . before [Ralph] Nader’s efforts” to make automakers, pharmaceutical companies and other assorted corporate defendants atone for their alleged sins, the “museum is not designed as a tribute to its founder.” But neither is it designed, as a Smithsonian exhibit might be, as a full warts-and-all telling of tort law history. If it were, there would be a wing dedicated to plaintiff lawyers’ judicial bribery, evidence manipulation and fraud. It could include falsified chest X-rays used in asbestos and silica litigation. And a special “no injury” class actions exhibit might highlight recent costly consumer lawsuits like those claiming Subway’s “footlong” sandwiches aren’t always quite a full foot long .
Readers should understand that the personal injury lawyers Nader’s museum lionizes are as self-interested as anyone else.
Tiger Joyce , Washington
The writer is president of the American Tort Reform Association.
